text: It’s #WorldTeachersDay. Thank you to the educators in Oregon and around the globe for their dedication and hard work to prepare students for success in school and in life.
I’m grateful to join my colleagues in this effort to honor Indigenous people, history, and culture.

Establishing Indigenous Peoples Day as a federal holiday is an opportunity to acknowledge the painful legacy of colonization that continues to be felt to this day and celebrate the countless contributions of Indigenous communities to our country.
Last Congress I voted for the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law to restore infrastructure in Oregon and across the country.
As we start the 2024 fiscal year, @USDOTFHWA will award Oregon almost $689 million to make needed improvements in our roads and bridges, including improvements to safety and efficiency.

Instead of paying loans that in some cases should have been forgiven years ago, these Oregonians can now put their money toward buying a house or starting a family. 

Those extra dollars will bring more financial security to Oregonian borrowers and help grow the economy.

In Oregon, 12,050 borrowers received $787 million in forgiveness through PSLF in the last two years, and an additional 12,430 borrowers received $607 million in forgiveness through IDR as of mid-September 2023.
These are typically borrowers who have been paying for years, and many made academic and career decisions based on the promise of these programs.
Great news: because of the Income-Driven Repayment and Public Service Loan Forgiveness plans, more borrowers in Oregon and across the country will see the balance of their debt forgiven.

I voted with all of my @HouseDemocrats colleagues, as well as several Republicans, to remove Speaker McCarthy from his position because I cannot in good conscience support a Speaker who has consistently empowered his conference’s most extreme members and pursued devastating cuts.

My town hall meetings in Portland, St. Helens, and Hillsboro are now scheduled for November 6, 7, and 9. Please note the updated location for the Portland town hall meeting. 

The town hall meetings in Seaside and Tillamook will still be held on Saturday, October 7.

NEW: Because of changes in the House calendar, I need to be in D.C. during the next two weeks so I have to reschedule 3 of my 5 town hall meetings.

During #BreastCancerAwarenessMonth we honor breast cancer survivors and fighters, like my mother, and uplift the importance of early detection. Women over 40, or who have other risk factors, should be screened for breast cancer every year.
And importantly, for the future of democracy we must continue to support Ukraine against the horrific and deadly attacks by Putin.

In the days and weeks ahead we must work together to fund government, keep out harmful provisions that would cut needed programs like SNAP, WIC, wildfire and disaster funding, and funding for public schools and health care.
Fortunately Congress kept the government open, but the continuing resolution we passed is for only 45 days.

The health care workers at Kaiser provide lifesaving and life sustaining care to people across NW Oregon. I’m grateful for their work, and urge Kaiser and SEIU to quickly negotiate a contract that benefits patients and workers.
The House leadership must now work in a bipartisan way to pass all of the funding bills without extreme MAGA provisions to avoid another near-crisis in 45 days.
Although I’m glad that House Republicans finally brought up a bill that earned bipartisan support, it never should have come down to the last minute.

No one wins in a government shutdown. The 45-day funding bill the House just passed with my support will keep the government open for now and avoid some of the worst consequences. I hope the Senate passes it promptly to avoid a shutdown.
I hope everyone celebrating has a wonderful Mid-Autumn Festival!
And I’ll continue working to invest in the health of children and families—investing more than just $11 dollars a month.

One proposal is to limit support for fresh fruit and vegetables to just $11 per month.

I’m fighting against these proposed cuts with partners like @NatWICAssoc and @IntFreshProduce.

WIC is an important nutrition program for low-income women, infants, and children. Unfortunately, House Republicans are trying to make cuts that would take food away from the mouths of moms and young children.

It’s not a surprise that the bill failed on the House floor.

The Senate has a bipartisan agreement to keep the government open. Speaker McCarthy should put that up for a vote immediately.

It would also cut education funding like Title I and IDEA, make dangerous cuts to nutrition programs like WIC and SNAP, slash resources for the 988 Suicide Lifeline, and cut funding for fighting the fentanyl crisis and wildfires.

Just a few – it would cut home energy assistance by close to 74% just as temperatures are starting to drop.

And thousands of families would lose affordable child care through Head Start.
The government funding bill House Republicans put up for a vote has extreme and harmful provisions in many areas.
The first student loan payments since the pause ended are due in October. I held a webinar and created a page on my website to help borrowers manage the transition back to repayment.
A government shutdown should not harm federal contractors. I’m glad to cosponsor this bill to provide them with backpay if there is a shutdown.

When Congress considers the Farm Bill, I will work to address food insecurity among students, seniors, and anyone who may be at risk of skipping meals or worrying about where they will get their next meal.
As we mark the one year anniversary of the #WHConfHungerHealth, I remain committed to improving food security programs to #EndHunger.

Many college students aren’t aware that they may qualify for food assistance, and others fear stigma if they seek help. I created the Opportunity to Address College Hunger Act to help remove barriers to accessing SNAP and other nutrition programs.

I didn’t throw away my shot to meet with Lin-Manuel Miranda and other Theatre Coalition leaders while they’re here in D.C.! We spoke about how arts education can support student mental health and how important it is for the community and the economy to support the arts.

I enjoyed spending time in rural Washington County this summer, and learned more about efforts to make our communities thrive. Thanks to Salmonberry Trail Foundation and Public Coast Farms for the great visits!

Millions of children could lose their child care slots if we don’t extend this critical funding. My colleagues across the aisle should recognize that affordable, accessible child care is economic infrastructure and join us in extending the funding.
September 30 is the last day to pass legislation to fund government and avoid a shutdown. It’s also the day important funding for the child care system is set to expire.

They want to slash funding to vital programs like WIC and Head Start. And if they can’t agree on a number, they’ll force 800,000+ federal workers to go without pay.

Our work in Congress should improve the lives of the people we represent. Let’s get to work.
House Republicans are threatening a government shutdown. Funding bills must be passed by September 30, but the Republicans can’t agree on how much to cut.

A skilled and diverse workforce is essential for a just transition to a green economy. 

I’m excited to see this new initiative to help young people get the skills they need to access growing job opportunities in clean energy and other green industries.

House Republicans want to slash Head Start funding, which would kick close to 50,000 kids out of the program. That’s wrong for children, families, providers, and the economy.

I joined my colleagues and advocates to stand together for Head Start. #FulfillThePromise
I applaud the Biden Administration for investing in community-driven solutions to the climate crisis. epa.gov/newsreleases/biden-h…

I wrote the Arts Education for All Act to help address these disparities. And with student mental health as a top concern, the arts can help bring healing and wellness.

It is unacceptable that there is less access to arts education for students from Black, Latino, and low-income families, especially when research shows that students who have arts education perform better in math, reading, and writing.
The arts spark creativity, critical thinking, and empathy in students. These skills benefit and enrich students throughout their lives regardless of what path they take. bonamici.house.gov/media/pre…
